comments.comment: Thanks for posting this. Was wondering why triple double-quote comments were being rendered. I thought triple single-quote comments should be allowed to render, but not triple double-quotes.

Hi <denchmark-link:https://github.com/imneonizer>@imneonizer</denchmark-link> and <denchmark-link:https://github.com/pybokeh>@pybokeh</denchmark-link>
Thanks for the bug report! Stepping back for a sec, Python allows you to type statements that don't actually do anything. For example: a = 10 a # This doesn't do anything, but it's valid Python. By default, Streamlit uses these "dead" statements as a magic notation to easily render to your app. So you can do things like: a = 10 a # This will render
"foo" # This will render
# This will render """ Hello """
x = "my string" # This will not render This is a feature we call <denchmark-link:https://streamlit.io/docs/api.html>magic</denchmark-link> . As described in the Streamlit docs, you can turn it off by adding the following to your config file (~/.streamlit/config.toml): [runner] magicEnabled = false
I thought triple single-quote comments should be allowed to render, but not triple double-quotes.
Python bytecode does not differentiate between different notations you can use to create a string. To the Python bytecode, all methods are just "string". So Streamlit can't tell by looking at the bytecode whether a string was initialized with single quotes, double quotes, or multi-line single/double quotes. <denchmark-h:hr></denchmark-h>
If you allow me to be pedantic for a sec , triple-quote notation isn't actually meant to be used for comments in Python. The only way to create comments in Python is with (which means Python actually does not support multi-line comments). Quotes / triple-quotes are only meant to be used to define string literals. See <denchmark-link:https://stackoverflow.com/a/7057988>https://stackoverflow.com/a/7057988</denchmark-link> for more info.
So in case if I wanted to use both magics and triple quote multil ine comments, is there any work around.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/tvst>@tvst</denchmark-link> Thanks for the edumacation :-) I swore I thought in the docs, the tutorials had used triple single quotes for magics, which is why I thought there was a distinction between single vs double quotes. Anyways, I will remember to just use # for multi-line comments then as opposed to triple quotes for mult-line comments.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/imneonizer>@imneonizer</denchmark-link> found out you can cheat a bit by doing this my_comment = ''' Please don't print this to the UI ''' by setting it to a variable it's not "dead" anymore and streamlit magic won't render it. It's a hack, but a workable one. It'd be nice to turn it off I agree.
